courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Introduction to Information Engineering
courses.description: This course previews the Information Engineering curriculum to enhance the understanding and interest of IE freshmen about their major. It will introduce some of the fundamental principles, as well as their practical relevance, underlying IE major courses covering subjects from bits and signals, networked systems, to real-life applications. Lectures by faculty members and IT industry experts will reveal how the IE curriculum links to important and challenging research areas and to different career paths impacting the society. Students will also receive hands-on training on system setup and applications to get prepared for follow-on lab courses.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. understand the basic structure and importance of IE curriculum

2. understand some fundamental principles of key areas in information engineering

3. understand the links from what they will learn to their future careers and to the society

4. develop basic skills in system setup and applications
courses.course_syllabus:
This course previews the Information Engineering curriculum to enhance the understanding and interest of IE freshmen about their major. It will introduce some of the fundamental principles, as well as their practical relevance, underlying IE major courses covering subjects from bits and signals, networked systems, to real-life applications. Lectures by faculty members and IT industry experts will reveal how the IE curriculum links to important and challenging research areas and to different career paths impacting the society. Students will also receive hands-on training on system setup and applications to get prepared for follow-on lab courses.

The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:
1. There are two course evaluations - one before the mid-term, and one at the end of the course. This is a formal channel for students to rate the teacher, the course, and the course tutors. Students can give specific comments or suggestions in addition to the numeric ratings.
2. Students can provide feedbacks using informal channels, such as email, or simply by discussing with the tutors or the instructor directly.

courses.description: Nowadays, many applications are written with the help of the Python programming language. This course aims to provide some hands-on experience with Python. Topics include the basic Python programming language syntax, Python data types and objects, Python functions, Python modules, basic Python data science tools (including the NumPy, the Pandas and the SciPy packages), basic Python visualization tools (including the Matplotlib and the Seaborn packages), multi-threaded programming and Python database tools. As part of this course, students will complete a project on a topic relevant to Engineering applications, such as web applications, data analysis, security and cryptography.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Basic Analog and Digital Circuits
courses.description: This course introduces the basic analysis of analog and digital electronic circuits, as well as the basic principles of communication circuits. The analog circuit analysis includes: basic circuit laws and theorems; mesh and nodal analysis; resonant circuits, steady-state and small signal analyses; electrical amplifiers. The digital logic circuit analysis includes Boolean algebra; logic gates; combinational logic circuit and sequential logic circuit design; synchronous and asynchronous sequential machine design. Overview of the computer architecture will be introduced. Examples of common electronic circuits will be discussed as case studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELEG2202 or ELEG2201 or ELEG1110 or ENGG2020 or ESTR2104 or ESTR2304
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. understand the basic principles of analog electronic circuits and digital logic systems
2. analyze and characterize simple analog or digital systems
3. understand the principles of common electronic circuits
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the basic analysis of analog and digital electronic circuits, as well as the basic principles of communication circuits. The analog circuit analysis includes: basic circuit laws and theorems; mesh and nodal analysis; resonant circuits, steady-state and small signal analyses; electrical amplifiers. The digital logic circuit analysis includes Boolean algebra; logic gates; combinational logic circuit and sequential logic circuit design; synchronous and asynchronous sequential machine design. Overview of the computer architecture will be introduced. Examples of common electronic circuits will be discussed as case studies.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Principles of Communication Systems
courses.description: This is a foundation course on telecommunication and related technologies. It describes the essential elements of a modern communication system. Students will learn the basic concepts in electrical communication, the operation principles and the performance requirements for a real-world communication system. The course content include signal representation and properties, amplitude modulation, angle modulation, analogue-to-digital signal conversion, demodulation and detection, pulse modulation, multiplexing, baseband transmission, passband transmission, inter-symbol interference, system performance evaluation and other topics. The course is the basis of various advanced courses on electrical and optical communications.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: ENGG2030 or ESTR2302 or ESTR2360 or IERG2051 or MIEG2051.
Not for students who have taken ELEG2310 or ENGG2310 or ESTR2300
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. describe the architecture of a communication system and explain the functions of each system component
2. describe how the signal is generated, demodulated and detected in a communication system
3. describe how noise, interference and channel distortion affect communication
4. describe the major analog modulation techniques and state their advantages and limitations
5. state the basic principles of digital transmission and describe different pulse modulation schemes
6. carry out basic system performance evaluation of a communication system
courses.course_syllabus: Overview on Communication Systems; Review of Fourier Transform; Concepts of Power, Spectrum and Bandwidth; Amplitude Modulation; Angle Modulation; Generation and Detection; Digital Representation of Analog Signals; Pulse Modulation; Multiplexing; Pulse Shaping and Inter-Symbol Interference (ISI), Digital Baseband Transmission; Digital Passband Transmission; Examples of Communication Systems.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course evaluation
The mid-term course evaluation aims at collecting timely feedback on teaching and learning related matters of the course. It is carried out by the course instructor(s) in the middle of the term (i.e., the 6th/7th week). Students are invited to provide written feedback on "the best aspects of the course so far", "aspects most in need of improvement", "How might the instructor improve his/her teaching", a few other questions. These feedback are valuable to the course instructors and teaching assistants, who may accordingly make adjustment on the teaching methods as well as course content.

2. End-of-term course evaluation
The end-of-term course evaluation is a formal and comprehensive evaluation process through students provide not only numerical ratings but also constructive suggestions on the course and teachers. The survey covers the aspects of students' overall satisfaction, course organization and objectives, pace of teaching, workload, etc.Statistical analysis of numerical ratings and written feedback are sent to the course instructor shortly after the end of term.

3. Face-to-face interaction
Students' feedback are collected through face-to-face interaction, which may take place in tutorial classes, laboratory sessions, individual consultation (with course instructor and/or teaching assistants).

4. Online platform
Students' feedback are collected via various types of online platforms, which include (and not limited to) email, Blackboard, Piazza.

5. Student experience questionnaire
Survey on student experience is carried out by the Centre for Learning Enhancement and Research. Students may provide feedback on specific courses in the survey.
courses.required_readings:
1. Simon Haykin and Michael Moher, Communication Systems, 5th Edition, Wiley, 2013.
2. B. P. Lathi, Zhi Ding, Modern Digital and Analog Communication Systems, 4th Edition, Oxford University Press, 2010
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Leon W. Couch II, Digital & Analog Communication Systems, 8th Edition Prentice-Hall, 2013.

4. F. G. Stremler, Introduction to Communication Systems, 3rd edition Prentice-Hall, 1990.

courses.description: The course introduces the fundamental principles of probability models and their engineering applications. It includes the topics in basic probability theory, random variables, common distributions and probability functions, moment generating function, inequalities, limit theorems, basic random processes, and basic Markov chains and Poisson processes. This is the foundation course to prepare the students for courses in communications and networking.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENGG2430, ENGG2450, ENGG2460, ENGG2470, ESTR2002, ESTR2005, ESTR2010, ESTR2012, ESTR2308, ESTR2362 or MIEG2440
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to

1. Understand and use the concepts including probability model, random variables, independence, conditioning, probability distribution, expectation, variance, and correlation.
2. Understand the process of using probability model and random variables to model situations with uncertainty.
3. Demonstrate a basic understanding and skill of solving relevant problems using the learned probability concepts based on the models.
4. Demonstrate a basic understanding and skill of using Law of Large Numbers and Central Limit Theorem to abstract and model systems and solve relevant problems.
5. Demonstrate a basic understanding of random processes and Markov processes, as well as the engineering applications.
courses.course_syllabus: The course introduces the fundamental principles of probability models and their engineering applications. It includes the topics in basic probability theory, random variables, common distributions and probability functions, moment generating function, inequalities, limit theorems, basic random processes, and basic Markov chains and Poisson processes. This is the foundation course to prepare the students for courses in communications and networking.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Microcontrollers and Embedded Systems
courses.description:
To learn an advanced microcontroller platform for the implementation of an embedded system. Using ARM Cortex platform, students will study the evolution of microcontroller architecture and learn the advanced features of Cortex’s registers, memory and I/O space allocation, bit-banding, buses, instruction set, interrupt control, fault handling and operation mode. Students will learn how to program the embedded system, particular the peripheral registers, using C-language as the primary language. Assembly language will also be introduced.

Advisory: Students are advised to take ELEG2201/IERG2060/ESTR2304/ENGG2020/ESTR2104 before taking this course
.

Co-requisite: IERG3810.
Not for students who have taken ELEG2401 or ELEG3230 or ELEG3701.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. analyze and select proper microcontroller for specific applications; and
2. develop an embedded system prototype using Arm Cortex-based microcontrollers

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Operating Systems in Practice: A Linux Perspective
courses.description: Linux is an operating system kernel and also refers to computer systems built upon the Linux kernel as well as many other tools and applications. Nowadays, Linux-based systems have been widely used in many places, from supercomputers to tiny embedded systems, from software development to scientific research. Understanding and mastering of Linux systems has become one of the mandatory skills for students from IT-related programmes. Although with search engines, people can find Linux-related knowledge and skills scattered across the Internet, this course aims to give a more systematic introduction to Linux and help students quickly build the thinking models to understand Linux system organization, design philosophy, working model, and useful tools that can boost daily working efficiency.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CSCI2100 or ESTR2102
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand Linux system design philosophy, organization, and operation model.
2. Complete simple Linux configurations and install software through different sources.
3. Use the common tools and write script programs to complete various tasks, including but not limited to remote login with ssh, text editing, source code version control, task automation, etc.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Information and Software Engineering Practice

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 1004

courses.description: Software Engineering practice such as requirement analysis and specifications, system design and integration, object-oriented designs and development, software testing and maintenance, software quality and performance metrics, documentation, CASE tools, project planning and management. Information engineering practice concerning software intellectual property rights, privacy, Internet commerce, entrepreneurship and public policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: CSCI2100 or ESTR2102
Not for students who have taken CSCI3100 or ENGG3820 or ESTR3308.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. acquire the basic skill of using a modern object-oriented language such as C#;

2. demonstrate an understanding on object-oriented programming, design patterns, and software development
methodologies; and

3. make the paradigm shift from traditional style of programming to the modern and abstract style of programming that is
based on interface.

In order to develop flexible and extensible software, students should appreciate the benefits of applying the following two fundamental principles
i) programming to an interface, not an implementation, and

ii) prefers object delegation over class inheritance.

Students are asked to work on a computer game project in two phases. In the first phase, a computer game is built. The students are then asked, in the second phase, to modify the code in the first phase so as to build a different game. If the design of the game in phase 1 is not sufficiently abstract, then it is very difficult to modify the code so as to change the game to a different one quickly. It is through this exercise that we hope the students could understand abstraction, the key concept in modern software design.
courses.course_syllabus: This course introduces object-oriented programming, requirement analysis and specifications, software life-cycles, software methodologies, software testings and software design patterns, software quality and performance metrics, project planning and management. Information engineering practice concerning software intellectual property rights, privacy, and public policies. Students are expected to implement a console software product in the course project. The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Networks: Technology, Economics, and Social Interactions
courses.description:
This course introduces various networking technologies we use each day and the fundamental ideas behind them. Different from many "theory-based" networking courses, this course is organized around a list of intriguing questions about the technological, social, and economical aspects of modern networks. The course will broadly cover topics on wireless networks, Internet, social networks, and network economics. We will introduce various methodologies such as graph theory, optimization theory, game theory, and pricing theory. The intended audience of this course includes undergraduates with majors in Information Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering and Electronic Engineering. It is also suitable for interested undergraduate students from Mathematics, and other Social Science majors.

Advisory: Students are expected to have taken Advanced Engineering Math course covering multivariate calculus and linear algebra.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR3302.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. understand the core concepts and fundamental methodologies in the field of networking; and

2. learn how to model and analyze emerging networking phenomenons.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
courses.description:
This course starts with the topic of Markov chain. It includes the Chapman-Kolmogorov equations, random walk, classification of states, limiting probabilities, and time reversibility. The second topic in the course is stopping time and martingales. This includes Wald's equation, the concept of martingale, and the martingale stopping theorem. The third topic is exponential distribution, Poisson distribution, and Poisson process. This includes the unique memoryless property of the exponential distribution, combining and splitting a Poisson random variable, method of randomization, various equivalent definitions for a Poisson process, and M/M/1 queue. Throughout the course, many examples of applications are related to communications and computers.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in probability.

Not for students who have taken ESTR3304 or IERG4140 or IERG5300 or ENGG5302 or MATH4240

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Social Media and Human Information Interaction

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description: Social media is one of the main sources of big data. This course aims to enable students to understand about social media and the interaction between human and information. It (1) examines the social and human dimensions of social media; (2) introduces the theories, models, and analysis techniques related to social media and human information interaction; and (3) discusses how to integrate theories and concepts in social media and human information interaction into the analytics and visualization of big data. Topics include: foundations of social media, human cognition and information behavior, online communities and social interactions, as well as infographic and big data visualization.

courses.description: This course offers a series of hands-on laboratory exercises for students to practice the design, implementation, and testing of the networking, computing and information service infrastructures of a modern enterprise.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Co-requisite: IERG3310 or ESTR3310
Not for students who have taken IERG3921.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the basic knowledge to:
1. Design, deploy and manage the information infrastructure of a modern enterprise.
2. Characterize, evaluate and optimize the performance of the information infrastructure of a modern enterprise.
courses.course_syllabus:
Building the network infrastructure including address planning and the configuration of different networking entities such as router, NAT and Firewall.

Setup of the computing infrastructure including the installation/ configuration of operating systems and other servers to support standard services such DNS, email, web-hosting and database.

Building a set of information services on the top of the computing and networking infrastructure. Examples include the support of web-portal, user-registration/ verification and login, shopping-cart and discussion-forum.

Deploy and apply measurement tools to monitor, test, debug and analyze the performance of different components of the information infrastructure.

courses.title: Product Design and Development

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 712
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 712
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 712

courses.description: The objective of the course is for students to gain basic theoretical and hands-on experience in designing viable hardware/software products that uses selected technologies to address specific needs in an entrepreneurial setting. Students would work in teams of two or three, and each team is required to propose, specify, and document a product-design up to a stage that prototyping is possible in a hypothetical startup situation. They are also required to critically examine different engineering products in real world settings, particularly local product designs, and participate in product design role-plays. Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected to understand the basic principles of user-need analysis and overall design process, improve their presentation of technical ideas, and foster a spirit of innovation.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the student should be able to:
1. Demonstrate solid understanding of a systematic design process, good practice in product design and application of such knowledge in product design projects.
2. Communicate technical ideas clearly through text, diagrams and oral presentations in a practical engineering setting.
3. Appreciate the importance of starting from the needs of the users rather than implementation details as the spirit of engineering, and the fun of developing innovative ideas into viable products.
4. Understand the conflict between design vision and feasibility, and the constraints of real world product development
This course contributes to the following IE Programme Learning Outcomes in a major way: 2, 4, 5,7.

courses.description: This hands-on project-oriented lab introduces the fundamental concepts, architectures, tools, languages, and frameworks in web applications development and deployment. After a series of lectures that cover the fundamentals, students will self-learn via online resources a set of language/tool/framework to design and implement a web application in multiple phases. This lab emphasizes on educating our students the fundamentals and empowers them to acquire skills/knowledge of specific language/tool/framework via self-learning so that they can adapt and tackle the future technological advances through life-long learning.

Not for students who have taken CSCI2720 or ESTR2106.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Demonstrate knowledge of the fundamental concepts in web applications development, including the role of programming language, development tool, and application framework.
2. Analyze the tradeoffs between different programming languages, development tools, and application frameworks for a given web application scenario.
3. Acquire knowledge via self-learning in a new language, tool, and framework for developing a new web application.
4. Design and implement a web application using the chosen language, tool, and framework.
5. Evaluate the web application and critique its limitations.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Real-time Embedded Systems
courses.description:
Real-time embedded systems are special embedded systems that must meet certain real-time requirements. Typical examples of real-time embedded systems include autonomous driving systems, smart manufacturing systems, transportation control systems, etc. Due to the real-time constraints, special hardware architecture and software structure should be used during the development of a real-time embedded system, including the use of direct memory access (DMA), memory management policy, task scheduling, inter-task communication, etc. This course will introduce the important concepts and development techniques of real-time embedded systems, including the following major topics:
1. Important concepts of real-time embedded systems, such as: hard real-time vs. software real-time constraints, periodic vs. aperiodic vs. sporadic events, event-driven vs. time-driven state transitions, preemptive vs. non-preemptive scheduling, etc.
2. Introduction to unique features of real-time operating systems (RTOS) compared with general-purpose operating systems (GPOS), in terms of task scheduling, resource allocation, etc.
3. Using the μC/OS-II and FreeRTOS to introduce the programming model of real-time embedded systems, including software structure, task assignment, inter-task synchronization and communication (e.g., semaphores, message queue), memory usage and management, and so on.
4. Testing, debugging and performance bench-marking of real-time embedded systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: IERG3060 or equivalent
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the important concepts in real-time embedded systems.
2. Be able to design and implement a real-time embedded system for a given task.
3. Be able to perform testing, debugging and performance analysis of a real-time embedded system.
courses.course_syllabus:
Real-time embedded systems are special embedded systems that must meet certain real-time requirements. Typical examples of real-time embedded systems include autonomous driving systems, smart manufacturing systems, transportation control systems, etc. Due to the real-time constraints, special hardware architecture and software structure should be used during the development of a real-time embedded system, including the use of direct memory access (DMA), memory management policy, task scheduling, inter-task communication, etc. This course will introduce the important concepts and development techniques of real-time embedded systems, including the following major topics:
1. Important concepts of real-time embedded systems, such as: hard real-time vs. software real-time constraints, periodic vs. aperiodic vs. sporadic events, event-driven vs. time-driven state transitions, preemptive vs. non-preemptive scheduling, etc.
2. Introduction to unique features of real-time operating systems (RTOS) compared with general-purpose operating systems (GPOS), in terms of task scheduling, resource allocation, etc.
3. Using the μC/OS-II and FreeRTOS to introduce the programming model of real-time embedded systems, including software structure, task assignment, inter-task synchronization and communication (e.g., semaphores, message queue), memory usage and management, and so on.
4. Testing, debugging and performance bench-marking of real-time embedded systems.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Building Scalable Internet-based Services
courses.description:
Mobile devices has greatly increased the demand of Internet-based services. Large-scale online services such as Pinterest and Instagram must be designed in a way such that they can be scaled up and scaled out in a rapid and seamless manner. This course will teach students how to build scalable online services and applications. In particular, the design principles and engineering considerations for different core components, including the front-end system, the load-balancer, performance monitoring, content-delivery networking, fault-tolerant mega data store, distributed messaging services, backend big data processing/ analytics will be discussed. As a course project, the students will prototype a scalable Internet service by leveraging industrial-strength component offerings from leading infrastructure and platform service providers.

Advisory note: Students are expected to have background in object oriented programming.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: IERG3080. Not for students who have taken ESTR4312.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand and analyse different design principles and considerations in building scalable systems
2. Understand the importance and working principles of different major components in such systems
3. Design and develop a scalable Internet-based service using open source and commercial tools available online
4. Identify issues and problems in an existing system and suggest solutions to increase scalability

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Networking Protocols and Systems
courses.description: This is a second course on computer networking protocols and systems. The introductory course, IERG 3310 Computer Networks, covers the basic principles of networks, the protocol stack, and network programming. This course covers additional topics related to the operation and management of the Internet as well as new and emerging network technologies. A major topic in this course is Internet routing and traffic engineering which studies the operational model of transit ISPs and local ISPs, and their peering agreements. The course covers new technologies and protocols including, for example, support for multimedia applications, streaming, VoIP, IPTV services, and architectures for content delivery and data center networking. The emerging issues covered in this course may include the support for mobility, convergence of different types of wired and wireless networks, and the design of next generation Internet protocols as well as the issues in the transition to these protocols.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: IERG3310 or ESTR3310
Not for students who have taken ESTR4302.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. Acquire a deeper understanding of network protocols and management based on how the Internet is operated by a multitude of ISPs.

2. Appreciate how multimedia applications and novel Internet services are supported by current/emerging Internet protocols and additional build blocks.

3. Appreciate how the Internet architecture is evolving with new technologies, applications and services.

4. Demonstrate the understanding of the specific challenges, possible solution-approaches and their tradeoffs in designing new Internet protocols, systems and architectures under changing technology constraints and user/application requirements.

courses.description: This course introduces the principles of wireless communication systems. Topics include digital cellular systems, physical characteristics of radio channels, fading channel, advanced digital modulation, spread spectrum and OFDM technology, diversity techniques, multiple access schemes, mobile network control and management, 4G and 5G technologies.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Functional Programming
courses.description:
Functional Programming is an important programming paradigm based on lambda-calculus. It has been widely used by many finance and trading companies (e.g., Jane Street) as well as big IT companies (e.g., Google, Facebook). Different from the imperative programming paradigm based on Turing Machines to specify the exact operation in each step, functional programming performs computation through evaluation and composition of expressions. These differences of the underlying computation model lead to many unique features, including algebraic data types, pattern matching, high-order functions, etc., and such features may help developers solve certain computation problems more efficiently. This course will introduce the following core topics about the functional programming paradigm:
1. Lambda Calculus
2. Data types, such as tuples, lists, records, variants, and algebraic data types
3. Pattern matching
4. Function as the first-class citizen and high-order functions
5. Recursive Function and Tail Recursion
6. Modular programming
7. Imperative programming inside functional programming
8. Advanced functional data types, e.g., hash tables, trees, sequences, monads
9. Typical algorithms in functional programming
10. Real-world applications of functional programming
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: IERG2080 or ESTR2306 or equivalent, or with instructor's written approval.
Not for students who have taken ESTR4328.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the key concepts and elements of functional programming
2. Be familiar with typical data types and algorithms in functional programming
3. Be able to use one functional programming language to solve real-world programming tasks

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Introduction to Cyber Security
courses.description:
Cyber Security is an important topic in modern information and communication technology. This course introduces students to major areas of Cyber Security, including introductions to cryptography, network security, computer security, and web security.

Advisory: Basic knowledge on Computer Networks are suggested.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CSCI4130 or ESTR4306 or IEMS5710
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. obtain an introductory level of understanding of major areas of cyber security, including cryptography, network security,
system security, and web security;

2. gain experiences in wireless network security and web security; and

3. able to apply the learning outcomes of this course towards a potential career in the governance of system, network, and
websites.

This course also paves the foundation to deeper studies in cyber security.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Introduction to Cryptography
courses.description:
Cryptography is essential in many cyber security goals and many application domains. This course introduces students with a foundation of theory of cryptography and its application, including introductions to number theory, symmetric-key cryptography, public-key cryptography, and a brief overview of the research advances (with respect to the latest research trend of the time).

1. Cryptography as a Scientific Discipline
2. Number Theory and RSA
3. The Basics of Provable Security
4. Secret Sharing
5. Basing Cryptography on Intractable Computations
6. Pseudorandom Generators and Pseudorandom Functions
7. Chosen Plaintext Attacks and Chosen Ciphertext Attacks
8. Message Authentication Codes and Hash Functions
9. Authenticated Encryption
10. Digital Signatures
11. Public-Key Encryption
12. Pairing-Based Cryptography
13. Special Topic, e.g., Overview of Latest Research Advances

Topics include, but are not limited to, the basics of two-dimensional signal processing, image priors, image filtering, edge detection, motion estimation, depth estimation, stereo matching, 3D geometry estimation from images, image feature matching, panorama stitching, image denoising and enhancement, and image segmentation and generation. courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Network Software Design and Programming
courses.description: This is a project-oriented course that teaches the development of network applications. Subject areas include object-oriented programming (C++ and Java); message-driven programming (windows); client-server systems design; interprocess communication; sockets: blocking and nonblocking I/O; multithreaded process; iterative and concurrent server designs; system-throughput bottlenecks; multimedia over network. Case studies: FTP, RPC, Web.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the principles and techniques in the design and development of network
software applications;

2. apply principles, techniques, and standard network APIs to implement a complete network software application in one or
more platforms; and

3. appraise the strengths and weaknesses of different development tools, I/O multiplexing models, protocol designs, and
server architectures with respect to the target network application characteristics.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Multimedia Coding and Processing
courses.description: This course introduces the principles of multimedia coding and processing. For multimedia coding, topics include, but are not limited to, the theory of data compression, Huffman coding, multi-symbol coding, and image, video, and audio encoding, quantization algorithms, and neural encoding. For multimedia processing, this course covers image processing, enhancement, transformation, machine learning, neural networks, image generation, and stylization.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: ENGG2030 or ESTR2206 or ESTR2302 or ESTR2360 or IERG2051 or MIEG2051.
Not for students who have taken IEMS5707.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the fundamentals of 2D LSI systems, 2D signal processing, and 2D transform techniques, such as the discrete Fourier transform and discrete cosine transform.
2. Understand the principles of light, color, human visual, and audio systems.
3. Understand the principles of multimedia coding, including quantization, Huffman coding, LZ77, LZ78, and LZW algorithms, subband coding, zonal coding, and threshold coding; understand how to combine these technologies to build actual codecs, including JPEG, audio encoding, and MPEG.
4. Understand the principles of deep learning frameworks, including network design, training data preparation, and back-propagation; understand the principles of generative models for image and video generation, including generative adversarial networks and diffusion models.
5. Design algorithms for image and video processing, including point operations, spatial filters, and geometric transformations.
6. Design multimedia systems utilizing artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and generative models.
7. Develop Python programming skills to implement multimedia processing algorithms.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the principles of multimedia coding and processing. Topics include, but are not limited to:

- Multimedia coding: data compression, quantization algorithms, Huffman coding, multi-symbol coding, color coding, image processing (including JPEG), audio coding (including subband coding), video compression (including H.26x and MPEG), and neural encoding.

- Multimedia processing: pointwise operations, image filtering and transformation, deep learning, image generation, and stylization.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Introduction to Internet of Things
courses.description:
The course introduces the principles, architectures and applications of Internet of Things (IoT) systems, which enable the networking and interaction of smart objects via various communication technologies. The design issues to be discussed include: smart object identification/positioning/tracking, smart sensors, data communication technologies for IoT, machine-to-machine communications and protocols, methodologies for large-scale sensing-data collection and analysis, system optimization and the related socio-economic impact. Emerging applications of IoT in various fields such as healthcare, energy management, transportation/ urban dynamics, inventory control, building/home automation, environmental monitoring/control, will also be studied.

Advisory: Basic knowledge on networking protocol and communication principles are required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. understand the principles and architectures of Internet of Things
2. understand the enabling communication technologies and various design considerations.
3. understand various emerging applications of the Internet of Things
4. design and apply the concept of the Internet of Things to enable smart engineering applications

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Positioning Principles and Technologies
courses.description: The course introduces the underlying principles, technologies, systems and applications of state-of-the-art positioning technologies. The principles of trilateration, triangulation, position tracking algorithms, time transfer positioning techniques, and related signal processing will be discussed. Measurement devices and sensors. Positioning technologies include cellular system, Bluetooth beacons, WiFi, Ultrawideband, infrared, acoustics, magnetics, laser scanning and tracking, sensor fusion, etc. Positioning systems include Global Navigation Satellite Systems, Inertial Navigation Systems, Wireless Sensor Network localization systems, and Laser-scanning and vision-based systems. Performance assessment of positioning systems. A system design project will be included.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: IERG2051 or ENGG2030 or MIEG2051 or ESTR2302 or ESTR2206 or ESTR2360
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to location positioning
Week 2: Coordinate systems and transformations
WeeK 3 & 4: Basics of positioning: trilateration, triangulation, Cramer-Rao bounds, position estimation/tracking algorithms based on least squares, maximum likelihood and Bayesian principles, extended Kalman filtering.
Week 5 & 6: Angle of arrival, received signal strength (RSSI) to determine distance, time-of-flight range measurement, time of arrival, time difference of arrival, measuring signal arrival time, spatial correspondence, interferometry, measurement devices and sensors
Week 7 & 8: Wireless Positioning technologies: cellular/LTE, Bluetooth beacons, WiFi, Ultrawideband (UWB), low-power wide-area network (LPWAN) technologies, infrared, laser scanning and tracking, acoustics, magnetics, image recognition, fingerprinting. Active and passive positioning. Sensor fusion.
Week 9: Machine learning for location positioning
Week 10 & 11: High-precision positioning systems: Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS), Surveying digital measuring systems, Inertial Navigation Systems (INS), Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) localization systems, and Laser-scanning and vision-based systems (LIDAR).
Week 12: Performance evaluation: accuracy, precision, probability and false positives, vulnerabilities and limitations
Week 13: Location-based (indoor and outdoor) services and applications

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Web-scale Information Analytics
courses.description:
The course discusses data-intensive analytics, and automated processing of very large amount of structured and unstructured information. We focus on leveraging the MapReduce paradigm to create parallel algorithms that can be scaled up to handle massive data sets such as those collected from the World Wide Web or other Internet systems and applications. We organize the course around a list of large-scale data analytic problems in practice. The required theories and methodologies for tackling each problem will be introduced. As such, the course only expects students to have solid knowledge in probability, statistics, linear algebra and computer programming skills. Topics to be covered include: the MapReduce computational model and its system architecture and realization in practice ; Finding Frequent Item-sets and Association Rules ; Finding Similar Items in high-dimensional data ; Dimensionality Reduction techniques ; Clustering ; Recommendation systems ; Analysis of Massive Graphs and its applications on the World Wide Web ; Large-scale supervised machine learning; Processing and mining of Data Streams and their applications on large-scale network/ online-activity monitoring.

Advisory: Basic hands-on operating system configuration and software installation skills covered in lab courses like IERG2602 and IERG3800 are required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CSCI5510 or ENGG4030 or ESTR4300.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. Model and formulate a wide range of large-scale data analytic problems in practice.

2. Design and implement scalable software to tackle large-scale data analytic problems.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Programming Big Data Systems
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the hands-on experience needed for a successful career in Big Data in the information technology industry. Many of the assignments will be completed on massive publicly available data sets giving them appropriate experience with the algorithms, mainstream platforms, and software tools needed to master programming for Big Data. The students will develop a solid background in provisioning, programming and applying Big Data systems and software.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre/Co-requisite: ENGG4030 or ESTR4300 or IERG4300.
Not for students who have taken ESTR4316 or IEMS5730.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the operating principles and be familiar with the tools to provision and manage data-center infrastructure at scale.
2. Understand and apply design patterns when programming for mainstream Big Data computational frameworks.
3. Understand the operating principles of different components and software tools in a Big Data processing stack.
4. Design and develop Big Data processing/ analytic applications using common open-source platforms and software tools.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course gives students a practical understanding of using open-source platforms and tools, e.g. those in the Apache Hadoop and Spark ecosystems, to perform Big Data processing and analytics. The focus is to provide hands-on training in managing, programming and applying Big Data platforms/ technologies. Topics to be covered include:

- Provision and manage data-center infrastructure at scale using tools such as OpenStack and Mesos.
- Design patterns, performance optimization and the implementation of common algorithms under mainstream computational frameworks/ abstractions such as Hadoop/MapReduce, Spark/RDD and Storm.
- Programming for Big Data collection, ingestion, transformation and migration using tools such as Apache Flume, Sqoop, Pig and Avro.
- Application programming/ interfacing with distributed Big Data stores such as Redis, Cassandra, MongoDB and HBase.
- Programming for batched and real-time Big Data queries using systems such as Hive, Impala, BigQuery/Drill and Spark SQL.
- Workflow coordination for Big Data Processing, e.g. using Oozie.
- Performing complex analytics using application libraries/ engines such as Mahout, MLib and GraphCreate.

The course syllabus and the specific set of Big Data programming tools and platforms to be covered may be updated from year to year.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Cloud Computing Security
courses.description: The course aims to address the security issues in cloud computing so as to assure a secure and efficient cloud environment for dynamic business environment. The discussion includes the basics of cloud computing environment and its common threats and attacks, analysis of security architecture in various cloud services model and deployment model, various software-based security tools to monitor and protect the flow of information into and out of the cloud, identity and access management, patch management, data security controls and requirement, etc. The lectures are supplemented by substantial practical security implementation work and application development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

Knowledge/Content Related:

• [CILO1] Understand the current security threat and future trend of Cloud Computing Security
• [CILO2] Design and develop applications with security features in Cloud Environment according to NIST standards
• [CILO3] Incorporate best security practices in Cloud Environment (such as latest Cloud Security Alliance Security Guidance, Cloud Control Matrix, ISO 27000 series, OWASP Top 10 risks)

Academic Skills/Competencies:

• [CILO4] Apply Information security governance and risk management to real life scenario
• [CILO5] Perform Cloud Computing Architecture Design (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS)

Other Learning Outcomes:

• [CILO6] Set up security testing/assessment tools
• [CILO7] Launch secure cloud application environment

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Networking Laboratory II
courses.description: This course allows students to have hands-on experiences in setting up the following three key components of the modern enterprise IT infrastructure: virtualization, IPv6, and wireless LAN.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: IERG3800
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Setup and manage large-scale Enterprise Networks with modern virtualization technology: Students will learn how to design their private cloud and HA infrastructure by using hypervisor setup at local and remote site. They need to setup secure tunnel for their enterprise network and remote data center network. L2TP will be used to support secure tunnel and VPNs.
2. Two layer firewall architectures: Setup and manage the two-layer firewall with heterogeneous platform equipment with the switches, routers, and servers.
3. Enterprise WLAN: Students learn how to build an enterprise Wireless LAN with different level of security and authentication settings, such as multiple SSID, captive web gateway, WEP, WPA, 802.1x, EAP/TLS and RADIUS
4. IPv6 : Students learn how to configure their routers and servers to support IPv6 environment and deploy the connectivity to the remote mobile clients over VPN tunnels.
5. Network monitoring and debugging: Students learn how to debug and test the performance of their networks

The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Cyber Security Laboratory
courses.description:
Learning cyber security is more than the grasp of security concepts, principles, theories and methodologies. An excellent cyber security professional needs lots of hands-on training before being able to solve real world problems independently. This is a companion laboratory course that extends the scope of IERG4130 (Introduction to Cyber Security) and aims to teach students how to use existing tools to solve cyber security problems. This course will also serve as the introductory training course for the Capture-the-Flag (CTF) competition so that our students can achieve better results in local, regional and international CTF competitions. The whole lab course will be organized around six topics:
1. Cryptography
2. Reverse Engineering
3. Web Exploitation
4. Binary Exploitation
5. Forensics
6. Miscellaneous problems

For each of the topics above, the students will learn the typical vulnerability types and attacking methods, as well as the commonly used tools for vulnerability discovery and exploitation, followed by solving given problems with those tools and techniques.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: IERG4130 or CSCI4130 or ESTR4306, or instructor's written approval.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand with different CTF problem types and typical strategies to solve CTF problems
2. Be familiar with commonly used tools for vulnerability discovery and exploitation.
3. Be able to apply the learned tools and techniques to analyze and solve CTF problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Learning cyber security is more than the grasp of security concepts, principles, theories and methodologies. An excellent cyber security professional needs lots of hands-on training before being able to solve real world problems independently. This is a companion laboratory course that extends the scope of IERG4130 (Introduction to Cyber Security) and aims to teach students how to use existing tools to solve cyber security problems. This course will also serve as the introductory training course for the Capture-the-Flag (CTF) competition so that our students can achieve better results in local, regional and international CTF competitions. The whole lab course will be organized around six topics:
1. Cryptography
2. Reverse Engineering
3. Web Exploitation
4. Binary Exploitation
5. Forensics
6. Miscellaneous problems

For each of the topics above, the students will learn the typical vulnerability types and attacking methods, as well as the commonly used tools for vulnerability discovery and exploitation, followed by solving given problems with those tools and techniques.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: AI Foundation Models, Systems and Applications
courses.description:
Foundation Models in Artificial Intelligence (AI), such as GPT, BERT, Claude and DALL-E, are large-scale neural networks that serve as a base for building a wide range of AI / Deep Learning applications. These models are pre-trained on massive amounts of data using distributed / parallel computing infrastructure. They are called foundation models because of their adaptability for many specific downstream tasks after fine-tuning or refinement. This graduate-level course explores the latest developments in AI foundation models, systems, and applications, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of how to design, implement, and deploy AI solutions in different domains by leveraging foundation models.

The course is designed for students who already have a background in deep learning and builds upon the knowledge gained in related introductory courses. It begins with a comprehensive coverage of the Transformer model, which has emerged as a universal and flexible learning architecture. Students will learn how state-of-the-art foundation models are constructed for different application domains using the Transformer as the basic building block. The course also covers how to leverage distributed / parallel computing infrastructure and methodologies to enable the training, serving, and deployment of foundation models in a scalable manner. Key aspects of foundation models including their emergent behavior, scaling laws, in-context learning ability, adaptation and augmentation are covered. The role of foundation models in the low-code, rapid development and adoption of new AI applications, as well as their societal considerations will also be discussed.

Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience through assignments, case studies, and a project, allowing them to develop a comprehensive understanding of AI foundation models and their applications in different domains.

Advisory note: A first course in Deep Learning or with equivalent background, or with instructor’s written approval.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the core principles and concepts underlying AI Foundation Models, including their mathematical foundations, computational methods, and algorithmic techniques.
2. Analyze and evaluate various systems, architectures, and frameworks related to AI Foundation Models, focusing on their strengths, limitations, and potential applications.
3. Design and realize applications based on AI Foundation Models, utilizing state-of-the-art tools and technologies, while adhering to safety considerations and best practices.
4. Critically assess the impact of AI Foundation Models on society, industry, and the environment, and explore the potential for interdisciplinary collaboration in addressing global challenges.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Advanced Networking Protocols and Systems
courses.description:
This is a graduate level course in computer networks. It covers advanced technologies, theory and applications of networking protocols and systems. It studies recent developments and emerging trend in various networking research areas such as:
Architecture and Economic aspects of the Internet; Network management, Operation and Traffic Engineering ; Network Measurement and Monitoring ; Domain-specific networking architectures and technologies, e.g., Data-Center, Content Distribution Networks and their corresponding challenges and solutions ; Network Algorithmics and Protocol Design ; Operating Systems and Hardware Support for Networking ; Modeling and performance analysis of protocols, systems and services. Each student is expected to complete a Term-Project as part of the course assessment.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in computer networks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: IEMS5715
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. Acquire a deeper understanding of network protocols and management based on how the Internet is operated by a
multitude of ISPs.
2. Appreciate how multimedia applications are supported by current/emerging Internet protocols and additional building
blocks.
3. Appreciate how the Internet is evolving with new technologies, applications and services.
4. Demonstrate the understanding of the specific challenges, possible solution-approaches and their tradeoffs in designing
advanced Internet protocols/ technologies at different layers of the protocol-stack to support new applications and services.
5. Apply the understanding and knowledge of 1 to 4 to analyze and design new Internet protocols according to changing
technology constraints and user/application/service requirements.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Signal Processing in Wireless Communications and Sensing
courses.description:
The course aims to provide students a hands-on learning experience on signal processing algorithms in real-world wireless communication and wireless sensing systems. To this end, the course will use some standard wireless LAN technologies as an example to teach students the principles, implementations, and evaluations of various signal processing algorithms for realizing wireless communications and wireless sensing. For the communication part, all the building blocks of transmitting and receiving wireless LAN signals will be covered. For the sensing part, advanced algorithms to process wireless LAN channel state information (CSI) data for enabling various sensing applications (e.g., human activity recognition, object sensing, device identification, and localization) will be discussed. Matlab or Python will be used to implement and evaluate the signal processing algorithms involved in this course.

Topics will include:
1. Introduction to wireless communication systems and wireless LAN systems
2. Wireless multipath channels and intersymbol interference
3. Orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) modulation and demodulation
4. Packet detection, frequency and time synchronization, and channel estimation and equalization in OFDM systems
5. MIMO-OFDM
6. Introduction to wireless sensing and its applications
7. Imperfections in OFDM systems and their implications on channel state information (CSI)
8. CSI data processing and feature extraction algorithms in common wireless sensing applications
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Pre-requisite: IERG3010/ESTR3300 or written waiver with endorsement from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Develop an understanding of various signal processing algorithms in real-world wireless communication and sensing systems
2. Understand how to generate and decode standard-compatible wireless LAN signals
3. Understand how to leverage wireless LAN signals to sense the physical environment

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Probabilistic Models and Inference Algorithms for Machine Learning
courses.description:
This course is a graduate level introduction to probabilistic models and inference algorithms, which constitute a common foundation for many methodologies in machine learning and related fields (e.g. computer vision, natural language processing, and data mining).

The course begins with a detailed exposition of probabilistic graphical models, then proceeds with various inference methods, including variational inference, belief propagation, and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). In the second part of the course, we then discuss the connections between probabilistic models and risk minimization, as well as how optimization-based methods can be used in
large-scale model estimation. Finally, the course will briefly discuss nonparametric models, e.g. Gaussian processes, and their use in practical applications.

Advisory: Basic knowledge on linear algebra, probability theory, optimization are required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. Understand the concepts of probabilistic graphical models
2. Understand representative techniques for probabilistic inference (MCMC, Belief propagation and variational inference) as well as the theoretical justification of these methods.
3. Devise graphical models for a given practical problem.
4. Choose an appropriate technique to perform probabilistic inference given a model.
5. Understand the challenges of Big Data, and can apply the techniques learned from the course to address some of these challenges.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Channel Coding and Modulation
courses.description: This course covers classic and new channel coding, and related modulation schemes. Topics include Reed-Solomon codes, convolutional codes, concatenated codes, low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes, and optionally, OFDM, MIMO, and network coding.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty;Exclusion: MATH4260 and IERG4200
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. understand the fundamentals of error control coding like minimum distance constraints, bounds on code sizes using
sphere packing and similar arguments;

2. learn the theory behind various code generation schemes: (i) linear block codes such as Hamming codes, Reed-Solomon codes, etc; (ii) concatenated codes, (iii) convolutional codes, etc.;

3. understand various decoding algorithms such as sequenctial decoding, trellis decoding, Viterbi algorithm, etc.; and

4. learn about more novel schemes like low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes and the associated iterative decoding
techniques.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Algorithms and Realization of Internet of Things Systems
courses.description:
This is a systems course that will enable students to have in-depth understanding of key information processing algorithms and their implementation for Internet of Things (IoT) systems. The topics cover 1) overview of basic signal processing algorithms such as FFT and digital filters; 2) advanced information processing algorithms such as acoustic and visual signal processing, spatial sensing, machine learning etc.; 3) their implementation on cutting-edge IoT platforms and key system issues of such as energy efficiency and real-time in the contexts of a set of key IoT applications such as smart health, environmental monitoring, smart homes/buildings, smart cities etc.

Students will work on an individual or team project to build an end-to-end IoT system. The project should have a significant information processing component and include implementation on real IoT platforms such as Raspberry Pi, Ardunio, wearable devices, smartphones etc, and. In addition to homework and lab assignments, students will also read and discuss latest publications in the areas of Internet of Things, Cyber-Physical Systems, mobile systems, and ubiquitous computing.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic understanding on signals and systems, signal processing or imaging processing and Internet of Things System.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Apply digital signal processing algorithms and advanced information processing algorithms in the design of IoT systems.
2. Design and implement new information processing algorithms for key IoT applications.
3. Learn the state-of-arts of related literature in Cyber-Physical Systems, mobile systems, and ubiquitous computing.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Edge AI and Applications
courses.description: This course aims to introduce various key concepts, technologies and applications in edge artificial intelligence (AI), which is the implementation of AI applications in an edge computing environment, which allows the computation to be processed close to where the data is located. The topics covered include, but are not limited to: basic concepts and fundamental technologies in edge AI, hardware for edge AI (e.g., embedded AI accelerators, FPGA, and infrastructures), interaction between edge AI and the cloud, machine learning techniques for model compression, security and privacy in edge AI, applications of edge AI for smart health and autonomous driving.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the background and fundamental concepts in edge AI, including benefits, terminology of technologies, use cases, and major players.
2. Understand the common hardware of edge AI systems.
3. Learn the software of edge AI systems, including edge-cloud cooperation, machine learning techniques in model compression.
4. Apply edge AI technologies to practical applications such as smart health, autonomous driving, large language models/foundation models on the edge.
courses.course_syllabus:
This graduate-level course provides a comprehensive study of the key concepts, technologies, and applications of Edge AI. It serves as a common foundation for many methodologies in machine learning and related fields such as IoT, autonomous systems, and smart health applications.

The course commences with a detailed exposition of basic concepts in Edge AI, fundamental technologies, and Edge AI hardware. Students will then learn about Edge AI and the cloud, exploring various inference methods including edge-cloud cooperation, cooperative multiple edges, and edge only. Then, this course introduces popular machine learning techniques like model pruning, compression, splitting, early exit, knowledge distillation, quantization, and compilation.

In the latter part of the course, the course introduces the applications of Edge AI in real-world scenarios, such as smart health applications and autonomous driving.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Network Information Theory
courses.description:
The course introduces the basic tools and techniques used in Network Information Theory. In particular the following topics are addressed: Multiple Access Channels, Broadcast Channels, Interference Channels, Channels with State, Relay Channels, and other topics. The course will be mathematical with an emphasis on proving theorems.

Advisory: A prior undergradaute level course in probability and/or information theory is highly recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion: IERG6154
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to understand, appreciate and develop the following concepts:

(i) Typical sets and concentration
(ii) probabilistic method
(iii) superposition coding and other achievability schemes
(iv) ideas for proving converses to coding theorems and outer bounds
(v) proficient (mathematically) with the nuances so as to enable the student to do high quality research.

In particular the following topics are addressed: Multiple Access Channels, Broadcast Channels, Interference Channels, Channels with State, Relay Channels, and other topics. The course will be mathematical with an emphasis on proving theorems.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Wireless and Mobile Networking
courses.description:
This course provides an in-depth introduction to the fundamentals and recent advances in wireless and mobile networking, focusing on WiFi and cellular networks. Students will explore core concepts such as wireless signal propagation, modulation and coding schemes, multiple access techniques, and network architectures. The course examines current standards like WiFi 6/6E/7 and 5G/5G Advanced, analyzing how these technologies meet modern communication demands.

Beyond the fundamentals, the course delves into advanced topics involving AI techniques applied to networking. Students will learn how machine learning and deep learning algorithms optimize network performance, enhance security, and enable intelligent resource management. Additionally, the course introduces networking techniques that support latency-critical applications, including live video streaming and real-time AI applications like virtual and augmented reality and embodied AI robots. Strategies to reduce latency and improve reliability—such as edge computing, time-sensitive networking, and advanced transport protocols—are discussed.

Advisory note: It is preferred to have taken courses in computer networks and communication systems beforehand.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Grasp fundamental principles of wireless and mobile networking, including wireless signal propagation, modulation and coding schemes, multiple access techniques, and network architectures.
2. Evaluate and compare current standards like WiFi 6/6E/7 and 5G/5G Advanced, understanding how these technologies meet modern communication requirements and address challenges.
3. Apply machine learning and deep learning algorithms to optimize network performance, enhance security, and manage network resources intelligently.
4. Develop networking solutions that support latency-sensitive applications, involving live video streaming, virtual and augmented reality, and AI-powered robots, demonstrating the ability to design and optimize networks for cutting-edge applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction to Wireless and Mobile Networking
2 Fundamentals of Wireless Communication
3 WiFi Networks: Standards and Technologies
4 Cellular Networks: Standards and Technologies
5 Radio Resource Management and Optimization
6 Mobility Management in Wireless Networks
7 Security in Wireless and Mobile Networks
8 AI for Wireless Network Optimization
9 AI for Network Management and Automation
10 Networking Techniques for Latency-Critical Applications
11 Real-Time AI Applications on Wireless and Mobile Networks
12 Future Trends and Course Wrap-up

courses.subject: IERG

courses.description:
This course will demonstrate examples of network coding. Topics include:
(1) Acyclic networks: linear network codes and desirable properties, existence and construction, static network codes.
(2) Cyclic networks: convolutional network codes.
Relations between network coding and classical algebraic coding theory will also be discussed.

1. demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the fundamentals of network coding.

2. apply the concepts of network coding to various communication systems and design linear network codes for various
applications.

3. take on research projects and read research papers on the subject.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Random Processes
courses.description:
This course starts with a review of probability theory (random variables, distributions, characteristic functions, limit theorems and notions of convergence, etc.). Then it introduces the definition and classifications of stochastic processes, and the basic concepts of stationary independent increments, martingales, Markov processes, stationary processes, renewal processes, point processes, et cetera. After that it covers in depth the discrete-time Markov chains (transition probability matrices, the Chapman-Kolmogorov equations, classification of states, recurrence, limit theorems, random walks, etc.), continuous-time Markov chains (Poisson processes, birth death processes, renewal processes, etc.), and martingales (supermartingales and submartingales, optional sampling/stopping theorem, etc.). This course will also cover applications of the random processes in areas such as queuing theory or stock markets. Some advanced topics may be included.

Advisory note: Students are expected to have a basic background in probability theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion: ENGG5302 or SEEM5580
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. understand the concepts and principles in probability theory, Markov chain, Martingale, queuing theory.
2. appreciate the role and function of probability models in various Engineering problem analysis.
3. associate some key concepts with short mnemonic expressions so that the acquired knowledge can last a long time.
4. use probability and random process as a tool and principled language in designing and evaluating systems with
randomness.
courses.course_syllabus:
Review of probability theory:
a) Random variables, distributions, infinite families of random variables, characteristic functions.
b) Limit theorems and notions of convergence.

Introduction to stochastic processes:
a) Definition and classifications of stochastic processes.
b) Stationary independent increments, martingales, Markov processes, stationary processes, renewal processes, point processes.

Discrete-time Markov chains:
a) Transition probability matrices and the Chapman-Kolmogorov equations.
b) Classification of states.
c) Recurrence.
d) Limit theorems for Markov chains.
e) Random walks.

Continuous-time Markov chains:
a) Poisson processes.
b) Birth death Processes.
c) Renewal processes.

Martingales:
a) Definitions and examples.
b) Supermartingales and submartingales.
c) Optional sampling theorem.

Applications in areas such as queuing theory or stock markets.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Security & Privacy in Cyber Systems
courses.description:
This course discusses the design and realization of security and privacy services in practical large-scale systems. Topics include: Online Identity and Authentication Management ; Safe Browsing ; Geolocation privacy ; Mobile payment systems with Smartcard/ Near Field Communications (NFC) ; e-cash ; Best privacy practices for Online Social Networks and Mobile applications ; Cloud Computing security and privacy: Trustworthy Cloud Infrastructure; Secure Outsourcing of Data and Computation ; Data Provenance; Virtual Machine security. Additional cyber security services/applications such as e-voting systems, secure and anonymous routing systems, digital rights management will also be covered.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in Cyber Security.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. be aware of the new security/privacy related problems associated with latest development in different cyber technologies.

2. acquire the knowledge of essential security and privacy primitives, protocols and algorithms which are used to support a
wide range of emerging systems and services in the cyber space.

3. demonstrate a deeper understanding of the specific challenges, possible solution approaches and their tradeoffs in the
design of security and privacy services for cyber systems.

4. apply the understanding and knowledge of 1, 2 and, 3 to analyze, improve and design new security and privacy services,
protocols and architectures for cyber systems.

Additional cyber security services/applications such as e-voting systems, secure and anonymous routing systems, digital rights management will also be covered.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Digital Forensics
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to digital forensics and cyber crime investigation. It will discuss techniques, methods, procedures and tools for applying forensic science and practice to the acquisition and analysis of evidence existing in digital form for the purposes of cyber crime investigation. Specific topics include computer (hard disk, file-systems) forensics, network/intrusion forensics, mobile device forensics, and a brief introduction to multimedia forensics. Techniques for detecting, tracking, dissecting and analyzing malware and other malicious cyberspace activities will also be covered.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in C/C++ programming skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

1. understand basic techniques, technologies and methodologies for conducting digital forensic analysis in
computing/communication devices, networks and services.

2. understand the design details of representative/emerging malicious software and their operating mechanisms.

3. apply the knowledge in 1 and 2 to perform digital forensic analysis in support of investigations of malicious cyberspace
activities.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is an introduction to digital forensics and cyber crime investigation. Techniques for detecting, tracking, dissecting and analyzing malware and other malicious cyberspace activities will also be covered.
