courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: IT Innovation and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Entrepreneur characteristics; product innovation: factors driving innovation, creation and evaluation of new product ideas, risk assessment of commercialization, critical factors for success; business planning: market assessment and strategy, business model, product planning, financial planning, cash flow; financing options, negotiation and deals; formation of a new venture: team, company and product building; execution and dealing with reality; exit strategies; case studies related to innovation and entrepreneurship in information engineering.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty; Exclusions: CMSC5730 or ENGG3802 or ENGG3803 or ENGG5700 or ESTR3502 or FTEC5570 or IEMS5712 or SEEM3450
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) The students will learn the 4 aspects of a framework of Entrepreneurship, namely
- Identification of Opportunity
- Venture Design (includes Business Model Design and Organization Design)
- Resource Mobilization
- Venture Execution

b) The students will learn the typical stages from idea creation to the formation of a startup company, with successful venture capital funding and management team in place.

c) They also learn how other entrepreneurs make decisions, do deals, analyze problems, allocate and mobilize scarce resources and succeed in local or even an international context.
courses.course_syllabus:
Entrepreneur characteristics; product innovation: factors driving innovation, creation and evaluation of new product ideas, risk assessment of commercialization, critical factors for success; business planning: market assessment and strategy, business model, product planning, financial planning, cash flow; financing options, negotiation and deals; formation of a new venture: team, company and product building; execution and dealing with reality; exit strategies; case studies related to innovation and entrepreneurship in information engineering.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Reinforcement Learning
courses.description:
This course aims to cover the fundamental topics relevant to Reinforcement Learning (RL), a computational learning approach where an agent tries to maximize the total amount of reward it receives while interacting with the complex and uncertain environments. The course content includes the basics of Markov Decision Processes, model-based and model-free RL techniques, policy optimization, RL distributed system design, as well as the case studies of RL for game playing such as AlphaGo, traffic simulation, and other robotics applications.

Advisory: Students are expected to have solid foundation on signal processing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:

Knowledge/Content Related:

• [CILO1] Understand the foundation of reinforcement learning and the relevant algorithms
• [CILO2] Familiar with various reinforcement learning algorithms such as model-based and model-free RL algorithms, on-policy and off-policy algorithms, and their strengths and weakness.
• [CILO3] Design and develop applications based on the framework of reinforcement learning

Academic Skills/Competencies:

• [CILO4] Apply and improve the reinforcement learning techniques for practical and academic problems
• [CILO5] Perform the system design and modeling using reinforcement learning

Other Learning Outcomes:

• [CILO6] Set up and run the simulation system environment

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Program Representation, Modeling and Understanding for Software Security
courses.description:
This course targets PhD students in the cyber security area. The contents are organized around the representation, modeling and understanding of programs, which will enable the students to be familiar and confident in dealing with research problems related to program analysis and software security, such as reverse engineering, vulnerability analysis, malware detection, and so on. Topics will include:
1. Low level program representation at binary and assembly code levels, PE and ELF file format, x86 and ARM assembly instructions, etc.
2. Intermediate level program representation, like Abstract Syntax Tree (AST), various intermediate language tarting for different program analysis tasks (such as VEX, BIL, LLVM IR and so on.), etc.
3. Transformation between different representations, including compile, assembly, decompile, disassemble, code lifting, etc.
4. Common program abstraction models, like Control Flow Graph, Data Flow Graph, Call Graph, etc.
5. Program representations for machine learning, like feature extraction, code embedding, etc.
6. Typical program understanding tasks, like taint analysis, code obfuscation and de-obfuscation, code similarity detection, information recovery, vulnerability discovery, malware detection, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Pre-requisite: IERG4130 or CSCI4130 or ESTR4306 or IEMS5710, or written waiver with endorsement from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Develop an understanding of different program representation forms and the application domains of those representations
2. Understand how to construct and when to adopt different program abstraction models

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Quantum Information Processing
courses.description:
This course offers an introduction to quantum information processing. It covers the fundamental concepts including superposition, entanglement, state preparation, unitary and non-unitary evolution, and quantum measurements. Various quantum algorithms like quantum teleportation, superdense coding, the Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm, the Shor algorithm, and the Grover algorithm are further discussed. Quantum error-correction coding schemes based on the stabilizer formalism are introduced to enhance the reliability of these algorithms. Standard mathematical and diagrammatic tools are introduced for describing the relevant objects and processes.

Advisory note: Solid understanding of linear algebra is required.
Pre-knowledge of quantum mechanics, graphical models, information theory, and coding theory is useful but is not required; relevant materials from these topics are introduced where required to make the course self-contained.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion: CSCI5370 and MAEG5110
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand various mathematical and diagrammatic frameworks that have been developed for quantum information processing
2. Analyze existing quantum circuits
3. Synthesize quantum circuits doing specific tasks

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Theory of Probability
courses.description:
The course covers the following topics: Construction of measures, integration, transformation, product spaces, distributions, expectation, Borel-Cantelli lemmas, characteristic functions, weak convergence, independence, weak law of large numbers, strong law of large numbers, central limit theorem, conditional expectation, Markov chains, stopping times and renewal times, martingales, martingale convergence Theorems, Doob's decomposition theorem, up-crossing inequality, and Birkhoff's ergodic theorem. The focus will be on mathematical rigor and development of all the tools to prove the results formally.

Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in probability and real analysis at undergraduate level.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion: IERG6300
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the rigorous foundations of probability theory
2. Apply certain standard techniques and arguments in their research problems
courses.course_syllabus:

The focus will be on mathematical rigor and development of all the tools to prove the results formally.
Advisory: Students are expected to have basic background in probability and real analysis at undergraduate level.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: AI for Science
courses.description:
This course introduces key AI technologies and their applications and systems in fundamental scientific fields. It covers the basics of AI, deep learning models, training methods, and the latest technology frameworks. The course delves into the interdisciplinary applications of AI in areas such as earth sciences, physics, chemistry, biology, and neuroscience, presenting recent advancements, technical challenges, and future trends. Focusing on these five major application areas, the course topics include weather forecasting, molecular property prediction, protein structure prediction, and neuron reconstruction. Through this course, students will not only understand the fundamental concepts and principles of AI in scientific research but also develop the ability to integrate AI with scientific practice.

Advisory note: It is preferred to have taken courses such as introduction to / fundamentals of artificial intelligence, machine learning, or deep learning beforehand.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. understand and explain fundamental concepts of AI and machine learning
2. describe the evolution of AI technologies in scientific research
3. discuss the application of AI techniques in chemistry, biology, and earth sciences
4. understand the requirements for implementing AI/ML tools in scientific domains
5. evaluate the ethical considerations and societal implications of deploying AI technologies in scientific research.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to AI for Science: the basics of artificial intelligence , the background and current status of AI for science, foundational technologies of deep learning
2. AI for earth technologies: basics of earth science and atmospheric science, AI applications in weather forcasting, seismic data analysis
3. AI for computational physics: introduction to computational physics, applications of AI in molecular simulation, potential function models, atomic environment representation
4. AI for chemistry: chemical fundamentals, molecular bonding theory, molecular structure representation, molecular property prediction, molecular generation, applications of language models in chemistry
5. AI for biology: computational issues in genomics, proteomics basics, large language models in genomics, protein mass spectrometry data analysis
6. AI for neuroscience: fundamentals of neuroscience, perception mechanism of brain system, brain signal decoding, neuron segmentation, brain-computer interface
7. AI for astronomy

Students are encouraged to give comments and make suggestions using the following channels:

2. Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, Aaron Gourville, Deep Learning, the MIT Press, 2016.
3. Alok Choudhary, Geoffrey Fox, Tony Hey, Artificial Intelligence for Science: A Deep Learning Revolution, World Scientific Publishing Company, 2023.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Multimodal Machine Learning
courses.description:
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental theories, methods, and applications of multimodal machine learning. It covers core concepts related to multimodal machine learning, including unimodal (such as images, text, video, audio, sensor data) and multimodal representation, alignment, reasoning, generation, and transference. These concepts include, but are not limited to, multimodal transformers, multimodal tensor fusion, cross-modal alignment, multimodal interaction with reinforcement learning, multimodal generation, neuro-symbolic models, mutual information, and multimodal graph networks. We will also review recent papers describing state-of-the-art probabilistic models and novel algorithms for Multimodal Machine Learning and discuss the current and upcoming challenges.

Advisory note: It is preferred to have taken courses such as introduction to / fundamentals of artificial intelligence, machine learning, or deep learning beforehand.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. understand the fundamental concepts of multimodal learning
2. understand the unimodal learning paradigms with different models
3. understand cross-modal representation learning, alignment, reasoning, generation, and transference.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Multimodal Learning: Multimodal basics, core challenges; multimodal application and datasets.
2. Unimodal Representations: Dimensions of heterogeneity, visual representations, language representations, signals, graph and other modalities
3. Multimodal Representations: Cross-modal interactions, multimodal fusion, coordinated representations
4. Multimodal alignment and grounding: Explicit alignment, Multimodal grounding, Self-attention transformer models, masking and multi-stream temporal modeling
5. Multimodal Transformers and Reasoning: Multimodal transformers, video and graph representations, structured and hierarchical models, memory models
6. Multimodal language grounding: Grounded semantics and pragmatics
7. Multimodal interaction and inference: Reinforcement learning, discrete structure learning, logical and causal inference, external knowledge
8. Multimodal generation: Translation, summarization, creation, VAEs, GANs, Diffusion models, Model evaluation and Ethics
9. Transference and New Research Directions: Modality transfer and co-learning; self-training and multitask learning
10. Summary and Final Project Presentations

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Convex and Stochastic Optimization and their Applications
courses.description: This course covers two powerful optimization tools, i.e., convex optimization and Markov decision process, and their applications in various IE/CSE/EE problems. The first part of the course will introduce convex optimization theory, including convex sets and convex functions, convex optimization problems, optimality conditions, optimization algorithms, and Lagrange duality. Advanced topics for designing control and optimization algorithms for large and decentralized settings will also be discussed, including primal- and dual-based decomposition, distributed/asynchronous algorithms, proximal optimizations, and stochastic approximation. The second part of the course will then introduce the Markov decision process and dynamic programming for tackling sequential decisions with significant uncertainty. Applications drawn from wireless communications, networked systems, and machine learning will be used to illustrate each topic. Emphasis will be on how to formulate a research problem into tractable forms so that it can be solved with these optimization tools.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to:
1. Understand the basic theory of convex optimization and Markov decision process, and how they are applied to various engineering problems.
2. Formulate a research question into a tractable optimization problem.
3. Derive centralized or distributed solutions that can be translated into practical algorithms/protocols.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction. Affine and convex sets, convex functions
2 Convex optimization problems and optimality conditions
3 Formulations of convex optimization problems in applications
4 Optimization algorithms
5 Lagrange duality
6 Separation theorems
7 Applications of duality, primal- and dual- controllers
8 Asynchronous algorithms, stochastic optimization, proximal algorithms
9 Markov decision program
10 Stochastic shortest path problems
11 Infinite horizon problems
12 Constrained MDP and Whittle index

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Computational Imaging Systems and Algorithms
courses.description:
Computational imaging systems are novel cameras that are combinations of optics, sensors, electronics,and algorithms that jointly enable new approaches for smart visual sensing and perception. It has a wide variety of applications in consumer electronics, autonomous driving, robotics, remote sensing, medical imaging, human computer interaction, machine vision, and scientific imaging. This course will cover core ideas and advanced topics of computational imaging systems and algorithms, including camera and image sensor models, high dynamc range imaging, coded imaging systems (aperture, exposure, illumination), burst photography for low-light imaging, 3D imaging, plenoptic functions and light field, Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF), compressive sensing, neuromorphic imaging, optical neural network, and more. Emphasis is on novel hardware and system design of computational cameras, as well as solving inverse problems with classic optimization algorithms and modern end-to-end learning-based methods. Students will learn the core principles of many computational imaging systems and implement key optimization-based and learning-based algorithms to solve inverse problems.

Advisory note: It is preferred to have taken courses in deep learning and signal processing beforehand.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For all students in Engineering Faculty
Exclusion= CSCI5670
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired:
1. core principles for digital cameras, camera ISP, and image sensors
2. optimization algorithms to solve inverse problems (classical and DNN-based)
3. knowledge of plenoptic function, light transport, and many novel computational camera designs
4. hands-on programming experience to implement algorithms for image/video quality enhancement tasks such as denoising, HDR, super-resolution, and deblur.
5. skills to characterize and optimize computational imaging systems for given tasks
6. abilities to design and apply computational imaging systems in related research areas
courses.course_syllabus:
• Camera and image sensor models (vs. Human Eye)
• Camera ISP pipeline and color processing
• High dynamic range imaging
• Coded imaging systems: aperture, exposure, illumination
• End-to-end optimization of computational cameras
• Burst photography for low-light imaging
• Compressive sensing, ADMM, KSVD, etc
• Light field, plenoptic function, NeRF
• 3D imaging systems: iToF, dToF, spotToF, SPAD, Lidar
• Neuromorphic imaging, event cameras
• Optical neural network
• Generative models for image restoration
• ... and more

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Network Information Theory
courses.description:
The course introduces the basic tools and techniques used in Network Information Theory. In particular the following topics are addressed: Multiple Access Channels, Broadcast Channels, Interference Channels, Channels with State, Relay Channels, and other topics. The course will be mathematical with an emphasis on proving theorems.

Advisory: A prior undergradaute level course in probability and/or information theory is highly recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For all students in Engineering Faculty
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to understand, appreciate and develop the following concepts:

(i) Typical sets and concentration
(ii) probabilistic method
(iii) superposition coding and other achievability schemes
(iv) ideas for proving converses to coding theorems and outer bounds
(v) proficient (mathematically) with the nuances so as to enable the student to do high quality research.

courses.subject: IERG
courses.title: Thesis Research
courses.description: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Information Engineering
courses.learning_outcomes: Under the regular supervision of the thesis advisor, the student learns how to formulate a research question in an area of his/her interest, articulate the long-term goals and shorter-term objectives of his/her research, critically review the background literatures, plan and conduct the research activities, become competent in the underpinning knowledge and skills, analyze, present and discuss the results thoroughly, and draw appropriate conclusions based on the findings. The student is expected to mature as a more independent researcher as he/she progresses in his/her research study.
courses.course_syllabus: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
We welcome students' comments and feedback on the course.

1. Informal online contact: Students can write their comments via email or newsgroup. Their supervisor will follow up with the comments.

2. Individual consulting: Students are welcome to visit their supervisor during office hours. They can exchange opinions to make the course better suits the students' need.
courses.required_readings: Individually assigned by the thesis advisor.
courses.recommended_readings: Individually assigned by the thesis advisor.
